{{Cleanup|date=May 2008}} {{Infobox VG |title =Warlords |collapsible = |state = |show image = |image = [[File:Warlords Flyer.png]] |caption = North American arcade flyer. |aspect ratio = |resolution = |developer =[[Atari]] |publisher =[[Atari]] |distributor = |license = |series = |engine = |version = |released ='''Arcade'''{{vgrelease|INT=1980}}'''Atari 2600'''{{vgrelease|NA=1981}}{{vgrelease|EU=1981}} |genre = |modes =[[Multi-player]] |ratings ={{vgratings|}} |platforms =[[Arcade game|Arcade]], [[Atari 2600]], [[Xbox Live Arcade]] |media =[[ROM Cartridge]] |requirements = |input =[[Joystick]] |cabinet =Upright, cocktail |arcade system = |cpu =[[M6502]] clocked at 1.512MHz |sound =[[POKEY]] clocked at 1.512MHz |display =[[Raster graphics|Raster]], 256x224, horizontal orientation }} '''''Warlords''''' is an [[video arcade|arcade]] game released by [[Atari]] in [[1980]]. The game resembles a combination of ''[[Breakout (arcade game)|Breakout]]'' and ''[[Quadrapong]]'' (an early Atari arcade game) in the sense that not only could up to 4 players play the game at the same time, but also the "forts" in the four corners of the screen were brick walls that could be broken with a flaming ball.
Warlords used spinner controllers for player control, and came in both an upright 2 player version and a 4 player cocktail version. The upright version uses a black and white monitor, and reflects the game image onto a mirror, with a backdrop of castles, giving the game a 3D feel. The upright version only supports up to two simultaneous players, which move through the levels as a team. The cocktail version is in color, and supported 1-4 players. 3-4 player games are free-for-alls, and the game would end as soon as one player wins. 1-2 player games play identical to the upright version.
According to the Atari video game production numbers, 1014 uprights were made, and 1253 cocktails were produced. The prototype version of warlords was called "Castles and Kings" and was in housed in a 4 player "Sprint 4 like" cabinet - it was huge. Only 2 versions of the prototype were made. The game was considered a success, however the large cabinet made it impossible to produce in large quantities nor was it feasible to install - hence the smaller cocktail design.
==Gameplay== The goal is to break through the other three players' walls and hit the player's (or computer's) icon (kings or knights) contained inside the fort. The last player left without having his icon hit gets 1 point. There are four [[fortification|forts]] (one in each corner of the screen), distinguished by the four colors [[orange (colour)|orange]], light [[green]], [[turquoise (color)|turquoise blue]], and [[purple]]. Each player has a shield that deflects the fireball that bounces off all four sides of the video screen. Players can capture and catapult the fireballs at opposing castles using their shield control and "power stone" push button.
== Atari 2600 version == A version was also released for the [[Atari 2600]] console in 1981. It features the use of [[paddle (game controller)|paddle controllers]] instead of [[joystick]]s. The 2600 version of ''Warlords'' is often cited as one of the more popular Atari 2600 titles by classic video gamers, and was voted the 25th greatest video game in the 100th issue of [[Game Informer]] (Aug 2001 issue).<ref>[http://www.mobygames.com/game/warlords_ Warlords for Atari 2600 - MobyGames<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The 2600 port was written by [[Carla Meninsky]], one of the two female game designers to work for Atari in the early 1980s.<ref name="Meninsky">{{cite web | url = http://www.atariage.com/programmer_page.html?ProgrammerID=37 | title = Programmers: Carla Meninsky | first = Albert | last = Yarusso | work = [[AtariAge]] | accessdate = December 3, 2010 }}</ref> According to Meninsky, the development of the 2600 version preceded development of the arcade version.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://willnicholes.com/interviews/CarlaMeninsky.htm | title = A conversation with Carla Meninsky | first = Will | last = Nicholes | date = May 1, 2011 | accessdate = July 14, 2011 }}</ref>
== Other versions == [[File:Warlords xbla.jpg|thumb|left|In 2008, a 3D version was released for [[Xbox Live Arcade]]]]
In 2004, Bryan Edewaard developed and published an unlicensed homebrew version of ''Warlords'' for the [[Atari 5200]] and [[Atari 8-bit family|Atari 8bit computers]] named ''Castle Crisis''.<ref>[http://www.atariage.com/software_page.html?SoftwareLabelID=2689 AtariAge - Atari 5200 - Castle Crisis (Self-Published)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
A port of this game, including a new "remix" version, is included in ''Retro Atari Classics'' for the [[Nintendo DS]]. It featured multiplayer play through wireless.<ref>http://www.atari.com/us/games/atari_classic_ds/ds</ref>
The game was released on the [[Xbox 360]] via [[Xbox Live Arcade]] on May 28, 2008, featuring a new special HD mode and [[Xbox Live Vision]] Camera support.<ref>[http://majornelson.com/archive/2008/05/27/this-week-on-arcade-buku-sudoku-and-warlords.aspx This week on Arcade: Buku Sudoku and Warlords - Xbox Lives Major Nelson<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
''Warlords'' was made available on [[Microsoft|Microsoft's]] ''[[Game Room]]'' service for its [[Xbox 360]] console and for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows-based]] [[personal computer|PC]]s in June 2010.
A new version of Warlords will be released on [[Xbox Live Arcade]] and [[PlayStation Network]] in January 2012.<ref>http://www.atari.com/node/3779</ref>
